SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL
Chemical composition and biological activities of the essential oil from
Eugenia stipitata McVaugh leaves
Cícero R. B. dos Santos a , Mariana G. V. Sampaio a , Lilian C. S. Vandesmet a , Bruno S. dos Santos a* , Saulo A. de Menezes b , Benedito Y. M. Portela b , Douglas W. R. Gomes b , Maria T. S. Correia a , Maria C. V. Gomez c , Irwin R. de Alencar Menezes d , Márcia V. da Silva a
a Biochemistry Department, Biocience Center, Federal University of Pernambuco – UFPE, Recife, Pernambuco, Brazil.
b Catholic University Center of Quixadá, Quixadá, Ceará, Brazil.
c Centre for the Development of Scientific Investigation - CEDIC, Fundación Moisés Bertoni /Laboratorios Diaz Gill, Asuncion, Paraguay.
d Pharmacology and Medicinal Chemistry, Regional University of Cariri, Crato, Ceara, Brazil.
*Corresponding Author: Bruno S. dos Santos. Biochemistry Department, Bioscience Center. Federal University of Pernambuco – UFPE, Recife (PE), Brazil. Address: Av. Prof. Moraes Rego, 1235, Cidade Universitária, CEP: 50.670-901. Phone: +55 (81) 2126.8540. E-mail: souza.farmacia@hotmail.com
Chemical composition and biological activities of the essential oil from
Eugenia stipitata McVaugh leaves
In the present study, the volatile components and cytotoxic, antibacterial, antioxidant, and antiprotozoal activities of the essential oil obtained from the leaves of Eugenia stipitata McVaugh (Myrtaceae) grown in the Brazilian Northeast region (Araripe) were investigated. The essential oil was obtained by hydrodistillation. The leaves of E. stipitata provided an oil yield of 0.13±0.01% (w/w). The volatile compounds in the essential oil of E. stipitata were analyzed using gas chromatography, and the volatile chemical composition was mainly composed of βeudesmol (15.28%), γ-eudesmol (10.85%), elemol (10.21%), and caryophyllene oxide (6.65%). The essential oil of E. stipitata was highly selective against Leishmania braziliensis and L. infantum promastigotes. The essential oil exhibited good antibacterial activity. E. stipitata essential oil showed low free-radical scavenging activity. Our results suggest that the E. stipitata essential oil is a relevant source of the primary compounds required for the development of antibacterial and antiprotozoal drugs.
Keywords: essential oil; Brazilian plant; Myrtaceae; Eugenia; antioxidant; antibacterial;
antiprotozoal

sections.heading: 1.1 Plant material
sections.text:
The leaves of Eugenia stipitata were collected from Serra dos Paus Dóias in
Chapada do Araripe, Exu, Pernambuco (7°21" S, 39°53" W; 884 m asl) between July and August 2017, under the authorization of Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) using the license SISBIO 59070. The plant material was identified and deposited by Dr. Maria Arlene Pessoa da Silva (Professor at the Regional University of Cariri, URCA) in the URCA Herbarium (Herbário Caririense Dárdano de Andrade Lima; HCDAL), under the registration number 13.054.

sections.heading: 1.2 Sample preparation and chemical characterization of E. stipitata essential oil
sections.text:
The essential oil of E. stipitata (ESEO) was obtained by hydrodistillation of 200 g
leaves for 4 hours using a Clevenger-type apparatus. ESEO was collected using a Pauster pipette and transferred to a beaker and the water remaining after the extractions was removed by adding anhydrous sodium sulphate (Na2SO4). ESEO was then transferred to an amber glass vial using a pipette, weighed and stored at 4 °C in the dark environment until use. The hydrodistillation was performed in triplicates. It was analyzed using gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (CG-MS) (Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010) with the Rtx®-5MS capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). Mass spectra were obtained at 70 eV (in electron ionization mode) with a scanning speed of 1.0 scan/s from 35-350 m/z, and helium (99.999%) was employed as the carrier gas (1 mL/min). The temperature was set at 100 °C (3 min), followed by 310 °C (3.5 °C/min).
The volatile components were identified by comparing the retention indices
obtained by co-injection of samples with C9–C30 linear hydrocarbons. The MS data acquired for each volatile component were matched with the data available in the mass spectral library of the gas chromatography system (NIST08 Mass Spectral Library; MassFinder 4; Wiley Registry™ of Mass Spectral Data 9th Edition) and other published mass spectral data (Adams 2007).
For quantitative analysis, a Shimadzu GC2010 Plus gas chromatograph equipped
with an FID detector and the same column and operating conditions as those described
above was used. The percentage volatile composition was determined using the normalization method from the GC peak areas in relation to the combined area of all peaks. All analyses were performed in triplicate.

sections.heading: 1.3.1 Cell culture
sections.text:
The assays with Trypanosoma cruzi were performed using the CL-B5 strain (lacZ
gene) (Buckner et al. 1996), kindly provided by Dr. F. Buckner from the Gorgas Memorial Institute (Panama). The epimastigotes were cultured at 28 °C in liver infusion tryptose broth (Difco, Detroit, MI, USA) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) (Gibco, Carlsbad, CA, USA), penicillin (Ern, SA, Barcelona, Spain), and streptomycin. Cultures of Leishmania braziliensis (MHOM/CO/88/UA301) and L. infantum (MHOM/ES/92/BCN83) were obtained from the Institute of Health Sciences Research (Paraguay). The strains were grown at 22 °C in Schneider's Drosophila medium supplemented with 20% FBS. The cytotoxicity assays were performed using NCTC-929 murine fibroblasts obtained from the National Collection of Culture Types. The cells were cultured in minimum essential medium supplemented with FBS (10%), penicillin G (100 U/ml), and streptomycin (100 mg/ml). The cultures were maintained at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere containing 5% CO2.

sections.heading: 1.3.2 Trypanocidal activity
sections.text:
The inhibition assays for epimastigotes were performed in 96-well microplates
(Vega et al. 2005). Briefly, the epimastigotes were seeded at 1 × 10 5 cells/mL in 200 μL, and the plates were incubated with ESEO or benznidazole at 28 ºC for 72 h. Subsequently, 50 µL of chlorophenol red-β-D galactopyranoside (CPRG; Roche, Indianapolis, IN, USA) solution (200 mM final concentration) was incubated at 37 °C for 6 h, and the microplates were then read at 595 nm. The trypanocidal activity of ESEO or benznidazole was estimated by regression analysis, and the result was expressed as LC50 (median lethal concentration—the concentration of ESEO or benznidazole required for 50% inhibition of epimastigotes). Benznidazole was used as the positive control.
1.3.3 Leishmanicidal activity
Promastigotes (2.5×10 5 parasites/well) were treated with ESEO (15.75–1000
μg/mL). ESEO was dissolved in a non-toxic concentration of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). After incubation for 48 h at 26 °C, resazurin solution (20 μL) was added, and the absorbance was determined at 595 nm. Miltefosine was used as the positive control. The leishmanicidal activity of ESEO or miltefosine was estimated by regression analysis, and the result was expressed as LC50 (median lethal concentration—the concentration of ESEO or miltefosine required for 50% inhibition of promastigotes).

sections.heading: 1.3.4 Antibacterial activity
sections.text:
Six bacterial strains, including three gram-positive (Staphylococcus aureus ATCC
29312, S. epidermidis UFPEDA183, and B. subtilis UFPEDA086) and three gramnegative bacteria (Klebsiella pneumoniae UFPEDA396, Pseudomonas aeruginosa UFPEDA416, and Escherichia coli UFPEDA224) were provided by the Microbial Culture Collection of the Department of Antibiotics of Federal University of Pernambuco (UFPEDA). Fresh cultures of each bacterial strain was prepared by incubating them on nutrient agar for 16 h at 37 °C and adjusted to approximately 10 6 CFU/mL with sterile saline (0.9% w/v). ESEO was dissolved separately in 0.5% DMSO as a co-solvent and added to Mueller–Hinton broth (MHB).
Serial dilutions of MHB containing ESEO were prepared in 96-well cell culture
microplates to obtain concentrations ranging from 16–1024 µg/mL. Then, 20 μL of bacterial suspension (10 6 CFU/mL) was inoculated in each well. For the negative control, MHB (without ESEO) was used to determine the sterility of the culture media, and the tested bacterial strains were inoculated separately in the culture media as positive controls of bacterial growth. Commercially available antibiotics (ampicillin and oxacillin) were used as positive controls for bacteria. The bioassay was conducted at 37 ºC for 24 h for bacteria. All experiments were repeated three times to confirm the obtained results.
The bacterial growth was assessed with colorimetric method indicator of cell
viability by adding 15 μL of resazurin (0.01% w/v) and subsequent incubation at 37 °C for 3 h. MIC was the lowest concentration of ESEO that inhibited bacterial growth (change in color of resazurin from blue to pink indicates bacterial growth), and MBC was the lowest concentration that completely prevented bacterial growth and was
further assessed by re-culturing the contents of wells without color change into MuellerHinton agar plates at 37 °C for 24 h.

sections.heading: 1.3.5 Cytotoxicity test
sections.text:
NCTC929 fibroblasts were seeded in 96-well flat-bottom microdilution plates at a
final concentration of 3 × 10 4 cells/well. The cells were grown at 37 °C in an atmosphere of 5% CO2. Then, the culture medium was removed and 200 µL of ESEO or drug was added, and the cells were re-cultured for 24 h. After this incubation for analyzing cell viability, 20 µL of a 2 mM solution of resazurin was added to each well. The microdilution plates were incubated for 3 h and absorbance was measured at 490 and 595 nm against the blank control. The toxicity against the fibroblast cells and protozoans were compared using the selectivity index (SI) ratio (LC50 for NCTC-929 cells/LC50 for protozoan).

sections.heading: 1.3.6 Antioxidant activity
sections.text:
The antioxidant activity of ESEO was measured using the 2,2-diphenyl-1-
picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) and 2,2′-azino-bis(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) (ABTS) assays. The DPPH radical scavenging activity was measured according to the procedure described by Brand-Williams (1995). Briefly, ESEO was dissolved separately in methanol, and 40 μL aliquots of different ESEO concentrations (or BHT/ascorbic acid solution) were mixed with 250 μL of DPPH solution (0.05 mg/mL adjusted to 0.7 absorbance at 517 nm) in a 96-well microplate and homogenized. The mixture was allowed to react in the dark for 30 min at 37 °C. Then, Absorbance was measured at 517 nm using a microplate spectrophotometer. BHT and ascorbic acid were used as the standard reference compounds. The results were expressed as IC50 values (the amount of sample necessary to decrease the absorbance of DPPH by 50%) calculated by linear regression analysis.
The ABTS scavenging assay was performed according to the procedure described
by Re (1999). Briefly, a 5 mL aliquot of stock ABTS solution (7 mM) was reacted with 88 μL potassium persulfate solution (140 mM) and kept in the dark at room temperature for 16 h until use. The ABTS solution was diluted in phosphate buffered saline (PBS) and adjusted to 0.70 absorbance at 734 nm. Subsequently, 150 μL of ABTS solution and 50 μL of different ESEO concentrations (or BHT/ascorbic acid solution) were added to a 96-well microplate and incubated at room temperature for 2 h. Absorbance was
measured at 734 nm. The results are expressed as IC50 values (the amount of sample necessary to decrease the absorbance of ABTS by 50%) calculated by linear regression analysis. All experiments were repeated at least thrice.

sections.heading: 1.4 Statistical analysis
sections.text:
All assays were performed in three biological and technical triplicates. The
obtained results were expressed as mean values with standard deviation. The median lethal concentration (LC50) values of ESEO was calculated using linear regression analysis. Data were analyzed using GraphPad Prism 7.0 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA, USA).
